heading.title: PART 8 ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS AND ORDERS [ss 102–138]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 8 ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS AND ORDERS [ss 102–138]
[s 129] s 129 No arrest on mesne process (cf Act No 52 1970, section 10)

leg:heading.title: No arrest on mesne process (cf Act No 52 1970, section 10)

p.text: No person is to be arrested on mesne process issued by the court.
This section does not affect any power of arrest exercisable pursuant to an arrest warrant issued under this or any other Act.

This section continues the position that existed under the Supreme Court 1970 — that there was no power to issue an injunction to restrain a person leaving the jurisdiction: Elliott v Elliott [1975] 1 NSWLR 148 ; McCosker v McCosker [1977] ACLD 715; and see also the NSW Law Reform Commission's Report No 14 (1971) para 18 which outlines the reasons for wording of the current provision. The Mareva asset preservation order, because it prevents removal of assets from the jurisdiction, has an effect similar to the former procedures for arrest of absconding debtors: see Bayer AG v Winter [1986] 1 All ER 733; [1986] 1 WLR 497 and Al Nahkel for Contracting & Trading Ltd v Lowe [1986] QB 235; [1986] 1 All ER 729 .
Legislation cited in [s 129.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 ss 486B, 487.

Specific statutory provisions may confer powers of arrest. For example, ss 486B and 487 of the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) permit the arrest of persons intending to abscond to avoid complying with obligations in connection with corporate windings up.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 130] s 130 Judgments not enforceable by certain means (cf Act No 52 1970, section 98)

leg:heading.title: Judgments not enforceable by certain means (cf Act No 52 1970, section 98)

p.text: A judgment or order is not enforceable against a person:
by any process for attachment of the person, or
by any process for committal of the person, or
by any writ of capias ad satisfaciendum.
Legislation cited in [s 130.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 4.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 1.6, Sch 1.
This section does not apply to proceedings in the Small Claims Division of the Local Court: see s 4 of the CPA, r 1.6 and Sch 1 of the UCPR.
Nothing in this Act or the uniform rules limits or otherwise affects the power of the court to attach or commit a person for contempt.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 132] s 132 Sheriff may appoint custodian for goods (cf Act No 9 1973, section 109(9))

leg:heading.title: Sheriff may appoint custodian for goods (cf Act No 9 1973, section 109(9))

p.text: After seizing a judgment debtor’s goods pursuant to a writ of delivery or writ for the levy of property, the Sheriff, by notice in writing served on:
the judgment debtor, or
any other person who has the custody of the goods,
may appoint the judgment debtor or other person as custodian of the goods pending their delivery or sale under the writ.
A custodian so appointed, and any other person aware that a custodian is so appointed, must not:
sell, give or otherwise deal with the goods, or
damage or destroy the goods, or
hide or remove the goods, or
cause, permit or allow the goods to be sold, given or otherwise dealt with, damaged or destroyed or hidden or removed,
otherwise than with the leave of the court or the written consent of the Sheriff.
Maximum penalty: 50 penalty units.

Prosecution of a person for an offence under subsection (2) does not prevent any other proceedings from being taken against the person in respect of an alleged failure to comply with a duty arising from the person’s appointment as a custodian of goods.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 133] s 133 Judgments and orders unenforceable until entered

leg:heading.title: Judgments and orders unenforceable until entered

p.text: A judgment or order of the court may not be enforced until it has been entered in accordance with the uniform rules.
This section extends to:
any judgment, order, determination or decree of a court, and
any adjudication or award of a person having authority to make an adjudication or award,
that may be filed or registered in the court, or of which a certificate may be filed or registered in the court, under any other Act or law.
In subsection (2), law includes:
a law of the Commonwealth, and
a law of another State or Territory, and
in relation to the Supreme Court, a law of a foreign country.
Legislation cited in [s 133.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 36.11.

A judgment is entered when it is either recorded, in accordance with the court’s practice, as having been entered, or when it is actually recorded in the court’s computerised record system: see UCPR r 36.11 .
The approved form for the registration/filing of a certificate of judgment/order is Form 45.
Legislation cited in [s 133.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Legal Profession Act 2004 Div 11, s 368(5).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 36.10, r 36.11(1), (3), s 368(5).
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 133(1), (2)(b).

Costs are assessed under Pt 3.2 Div 11 of the Legal Profession Act 2004 (LPA 2004). LPA 2004 s 368(5) provides that a certificate of costs that has been filed in a court registry is “with no further action” taken to be a judgment of the court for the amount of any unpaid costs: see UCPR r 36.10 . This means that the filed certificate may be enforced as a judgment, but it does not become an actual court judgment: Frumar v Owners of Strata Plan 36957 [2010] NSWCA 172; BC201006901 at [42] . A judgment based on a costs certificate may, unlike an ordinary judgment, be set aside on any ground on which the certificate itself may be impugned: Doyle v Hall Chadwick [2007] NSWCA 159; BC200705261 at [47]–[54] .

The stipulation that the filed certificate is taken to be a judgment “with no further action” raises a question whether the certificate has to be formally “entered” before it is enforceable as a judgment: Coshott v Barry [2012] NSWSC 850; BC201206340 at [45] , or whether a LPA 2004 s 368(5) is inconsistent with any requirement for formal “entry of judgment”: Frumar v Owners of Strata Plan 36957 [2010] NSWCA 172; BC201006901 Handley JA at [42]. CPA s 133(1) and (2)(b) suggest that formal “entry” is required, but it is arguable that the filing of the certificate (assuming it is recorded in the court’s computerised court record system) itself constitutes the relevant “entry”: see UCPR r 36.11(1) and (3) .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 134] s 134 Stale judgments and orders enforceable only by leave (cf Act No 9 1973, section 84A)

leg:heading.title: Stale judgments and orders enforceable only by leave (cf Act No 9 1973, section 84A)

p.text: An application by a judgment creditor for:
a writ of execution, or
a garnishee order, or
a charging order, or
an order for examination,
In this section, prescribed period means 12 years or, if the uniform rules prescribe a different period, the period so prescribed.
The court may, by order, give directions with respect to the enforcement of its judgments and orders.
Without limiting subsection (1), the court may make any of the following orders:
an order authorising the Sheriff to enter premises for the purpose of taking possession of goods under a writ of execution,
an order prohibiting the Sheriff from taking any further action on a writ,
an order prohibiting any other person from taking any further action, either permanently or until a specified day, to enforce a judgment or order of the court,

an order requiring the Registrar-General to cancel any recording of a writ for the levy of property that, under section 105 of the Real Property Act 1900, has been made in the Register under that Act, either generally or in relation to specified land.

level.toc-caption: [s 135.2] Enforcement of judgments and orders — ordinary procedures

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 135.2] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 102, s 104, s 105, s 106(1)(a), 106(2), s 92.

heading.title: Enforcement of judgments and orders — ordinary procedures

p.text: The basic procedure for enforcing a judgment or order is by the issue of one of the three different kinds of “writ of execution” provided for in s 102 CPA. The issue of a writ of execution requires an application by way of Notice of Motion: UCPR r 39.2 ; and must be supported by an affidavit complying with r 39.3 UCPR. The three different kinds of writ of execution, together with the relevant provisions of the Act and Rules that apply to each particular form of writ, and the approved Forms, are as follows:
Writ for the levy of property — for enforcement of a judgment or order for the payment of money:
Writ of delivery — for enforcement of a judgment or order for the delivery of goods:
see CPA s 105 ; UCPR rr 39.1 and 39.3 ;
Writ of possession — for enforcement of a judgment or order for possession of land:
Form 50 (form of writ) reproduced at [132,450] .

level.toc-caption: [s 135.3] Restrictions on order for entry by Sheriff

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 135.3] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 39.52.

heading.title: Restrictions on order for entry by Sheriff

p.text: An order authorising entry by the sheriff for the purpose of taking possession of goods may only be made in special circumstances or where the sheriff has previously been refused entry: UCPR r 39.52 .
Legislation cited in [s 135.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 13.2, r 51.44.

The directions power in the present section includes a power to stay execution. That stay power is additional to the general stay power conferred by CPA s 67, any incidental stay power (Carr v Royal Exchange Assurance Corp (1864) 5 B & S 941; Ellis v Scott [1964] 2 All ER 987; [1964] 1 WLR 976 ) and to the power to stay pending appeal to the Court of Appeal: see UCPR r 51.44 . The power to stay is exercisable whenever the requirements of justice so demand, its exercise is subject to the restraint implicit in that criterion but not otherwise confined to particular, or closed categories of, circumstances: The Annot Lyle (1886) 11 PD 114 at 116 ; Tringali v Stewardson Stubbs & Collett Pty Ltd [1966] 1 NSWR 354; (1966) 66 SR (NSW) 335 at 344 ; Ferris v Lambton (1905) 22 WN (NSW) 56 . Apart from cases involving the grant of a stay pending an appeal there are a number of instances where the grant of a stay may be appropriate. Examples of those circumstances include the following:
Where a defendant has a right of set off against the plaintiff’s judgment: Re a Debtor [1951] Ch 612 ; Attorney-General v Emerson (1889) 24 QBD 56 ;

where the judgment debt does not finally determine the parties respective entitlements and the judgment creditor is insolvent: Grosvenor Constructions (NSW) Pty Ltd (in admin) v Musico [2004] NSWSC 344; BC200402162 (judgment for progress payments under the Building and Construction Industry Security of Payment Act 1999) and also see Brodyn Pty Ltd (t/as Time Cost and Quality) v Davenport (2004) 61 NSWLR 421; [2004] NSWCA 394; BC200407256 at [86], [87] ;
where the defendant has a bona fide claim for indemnity against a third person: State Bank of Victoria v Parry [1989] WAR 240 .

level.toc-caption: [s 135.7] Stay of execution — writ of levy of property

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 135.7] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Real Property Act 1900 s 105, s 105A(6).
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 135(2)(b).

heading.title: Stay of execution — writ of levy of property

p.text: Section 105 of the Real Property Act 1900 permits applications to record on titles a writ for levy of property issued in execution of a judgment. Registration of a writ for levy of property on a title under the Real Property Act 1900 permits the Sheriff to sell the land under the writ and to give an effective transfer pursuant to the sale. It also has the effect of preventing dealings with the land while the writ remains registered for a period of 3 months from the date on which the writ is recorded on the title. It ceases to have that effect after the 3 months: s 105A(6) Real Property Act 1900. See Biseja Pty Ltd v NSI Group Pty Ltd [2007] NSWSC 283; BC200704316 for successful application for an order pursuant to s 135(2)(b) CPA in aid of a stay, requiring the Registrar-General to cancel the recording of writs of levy of property on titles.

level.toc-caption: [s 135.8] Stay of execution — writ for possession of land

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 135.8] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 [s 20.5].

heading.title: Stay of execution — writ for possession of land

p.text: There are various preconditions to obtaining not only a judgment for possession of land but also writ for possession to enforce the judgment. (Those restrictions are summarised in [s 20.5] .) Even where those restrictions have been satisfied, and a writ for possession has been issued, the court may stay the execution of a writ for possession. An urgent application for a stay may be dealt with on an ex parte basis. (The procedure for a stay application is set out in Practice Note SC CL 6 paras 28–36.) The grounds typically relied on to support a stay application are (i) proposed repayment of the relevant loan, usually by refinancing , (ii) proposed orderly sale of the property, (iii) an application to set aside the judgment for possession and (iv) hardship. Where the court is satisfied that a proposed repayment is realistically achievable or that a sale proposal is genuine, and the sale proceeds likely sufficient to satisfy the plaintiff’s claim, a stay will generally be appropriate. A stay will also be appropriate where the court is satisfied the defendant has a proper defence on the merits, and has an acceptable explanation for delay in advancing it. Hardship alone is unlikely to provide a sufficient basis to order the stay of a writ for possession: see generally GE Personal Finance Pty Ltd v Smith (2006) NSW ConvR ¶56-164; [2006] NSWSC 889; BC200606844 per Johnson J at [9]–[30] (stay of 1 week granted — payment of arrears and imminent refinancing); Secure Funding Pty Ltd v Webster [2008] NSWSC 443; BC200803590 at [23] ff (no stay granted — application based on proposed sale of property but execution of the writ complete). If a stay has previously been granted, a further application is unlikely to be granted ex parte: see Practice Note SC CL 6 para 32; see also GE Personal Finance Pty Ltd v Smith, aboveat [7].

An application for a stay of execution does not operate as an approbation of the judgment so as to prevent a later application to have the judgment set aside: Evans v Bartlam [1937] AC 473; [1937] 2 All ER 646 . A stay of execution only prevents the judgment creditor from issuing execution on the judgment. It does not prevent them from enforcing any rights they have independently of the judgment: Clifton Securities Ltd v Huntley [1948] 2 All ER 283 . Execution may issue immediately the period of the stay has expired: Ibbotson v Hudson (1884) 4 WN (NSW) 154; L Joseph Pty Ltd v Gray (1939) 56 WN (NSW) 190 .

A stay of execution pending appeal will be granted where a successful appeal would be useless unless the stay were granted: Polini v Gray (1879) 12 Ch D 438 . Factors relevant to the granting of a stay include the improbability of the appellant recovering back the judgment amount if the appeal was successful, the likelihood of the appeal succeeding, the size of the damages awarded at first instance, the amount of the respondent's legal costs of the appeal and the likelihood of the damages being used to fund those costs: Andrews v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd [1979] 2 NSWLR 184 at 188 . A judgment for the repayment of money will not usually be stayed pending appeal unless it can be shown that the respondent will not be able to repay the money if the appeal is successful: The Annot Lyle (1886) 11 PD 114 ; Scarborough v Lew's Junction Stores Pty Ltd [1963] VR 129 ; Carr v Swart [2007] NSWCA 135; BC200704532 (necessity to attempt to reconcile the tension between the judgment creditor’s need and the degree of risk of that full amount of judgment debt would not be recoverable if appeal successful — stay conditional on payment to stakeholder). The same general principle applies to an appeal in relation to an order for the payment of costs: Barker v Lavery (1885) 14 QBD 769 . However, a stay may be granted on the personal undertaking of solicitors for the respondent to repay the costs if the appeal is successful: Morgan v Elford (1876) 4 Ch D 352 ; Grant v Banque Franco-Egyptienne (1878) 3 CPD 202; BC7600095 ; Wilson v Church (No 2) (1879) 12 Ch D 454 .

The court has a wide discretion as to whether any terms should be imposed and if so, as to the nature of the terms. Appropriate terms may include the payment of part of the judgment to the plaintiff: Andrews v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd [1979] 2 NSWLR 184 ; the provision of security: Rosengrens Ltd v Safe Deposit Centres Ltd [1984] 3 All ER 198 ; or payment into an interest bearing stakeholder’s account: Carr v Swart [2007] NSWCA 135; BC200704532 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 136] s 136 Appropriation of payments towards judgment debt

leg:heading.title: Appropriation of payments towards judgment debt

p.text: Unless the court otherwise orders, any payment made on account of a judgment debt is to be appropriated:
firstly, towards such part of the judgment debt as comprises interest payable under section 101, and
secondly, towards the balance of the judgment debt.

The requirement to appropriate payments first to interest and then to the principal of the judgment debt settles any question that might otherwise have arisen about the entitlement of the judgment debtor to determine the nature of the payment being made. Under the general law a debtor may allocate repayments principal or interest and the creditor is bound by the appropriation. In the absence of allocation by the debtor, the creditor may determine the appropriation of the payment: If neither debtor nor creditor made an appropriation, the payment was presumed to be applied first in reduction of interest: Chase v Box (1702) Freem Ch 261; 22 ER 1197; Re Mangan; Ex parte Andrew (1983) 123 ALR 633; (1983) NSW ConvR ¶55-149 ; Falk v Haugh (1935) 53 CLR 163 at 173 per Rich, Dixon, Evatt and McTiernan JJ. See also The Laws of Australia, 7.5.29–7.5.32, especially [31], [32]. However, these authorities general law authorities were distinguishable once the principal liability had merged in a judgment: Re Mangan; Ex parte Andrew , above, at 638 per Beaumont J and, by analogy, The Laws of Australia at [30], and in Red Lea Chickens Pty Ltd v Tansey (NSWCA, Kirby ACJ, Clarke, Sheller JJA, CA 40368/93, 17 July 1995, unreported, BC9505123), the assumption by all parties and all three judges of the Court of Appeal was that any payments were to be appropriated first towards the accruing interest. That assumed position now applies by virtue of the present section.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 137] s 137 Execution of judgments and orders for costs

leg:heading.title: Execution of judgments and orders for costs

p.text: A judgment may be enforced in relation to costs separately from its enforcement in relation to matters other than costs.
Unless the court otherwise orders, the costs recoverable under a writ of execution, garnishee order or charging order include:
costs in relation to any prior writ of execution, garnishee order or charging order in relation to the same judgment, whether or not the prior writ or order was productive, and
money recoverable under section 107(1) of the Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 of the Commonwealth.

This section abrogates the general rule that prevented the issue of a second writ of execution until the first has been returned unsatisfied either in whole or in part: Re Broughton (1916) 17 SR (NSW) 29; 33 WN (NSW) 188 ; Re Milne (1949) 14 ABC 192. Before the present section (and similar rules of court: see former SCR Pt 44 r 6) the practice was that the issue of execution prior to taxation constituted a waiver of costs: Harris v Jewell [1883] WN 216. The present section permits separate execution without imposing any restriction on the sequence in which the judgment and costs may be enforced. In this respect, it alters the position that existed under former rules, which only permitted execution for the judgment first and costs later: O'Neil v Hart (No 2) [1905] VLR 259; (1904) 10 ALR 245b .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 138] s 138 Other methods of enforcing judgments

p.text: Nothing in this Part limits the manner in which a judgment or order of the court may be enforced apart from this Act.
Without limiting subsection (1), nothing in this Part prevents the court:

from issuing consecutive writs for the levy of property against the same judgment debtor, or making consecutive garnishee orders or consecutive charging orders in respect of the same judgment debtor, in respect of the same judgment debt, or
from making concurrent garnishee orders against different garnishees, or consecutive garnishee orders against the same garnishee, in respect of the same judgment debt.
